text: ਮੋਹੁ ਮਲਿ ਬਿਵਸਿ ਕੀਅਉ ਕਾਮੁ ਗਹਿ ਕੇਸ ਪਛਾੜ੍ਯਉ ॥

translation.text: He has crushed and overpowered emotional attachment. He seized sexual desire by the hair, and threw it down.

transliteration.text: mōh mal bivas kīau kām gah kēs pashāryau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਕ੍ਰੋਧੁ ਖੰਡਿ ਪਰਚੰਡਿ ਲੋਭੁ ਅਪਮਾਨ ਸਿਉ ਝਾੜ੍ਯਉ ॥

translation.text: With His Power, He cut anger into pieces, and sent greed away in disgrace.

transliteration.text: krōdh khand parachand lōbh apamān siu jhāryau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਜਨਮੁ ਕਾਲੁ ਕਰ ਜੋੜਿ ਹੁਕਮੁ ਜੋ ਹੋਇ ਸੁ ਮੰਨੈ ॥

translation.text: Life and death, with palms pressed together, respect and obey the Hukam of His Command.

transliteration.text: janam kāl kar jōr hukam jō hōi s mannai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਭਵ ਸਾਗਰੁ ਬੰਧਿਅਉ ਸਿਖ ਤਾਰੇ ਸੁਪ੍ਰਸੰਨੈ ॥

translation.text: He brought the terrifying world-ocean under His Control; by His Pleasure, He carried His Sikhs across.

transliteration.text: bhav sāgar bandhiau sikh tārē suprasannai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਸਿਰਿ ਆਤਪਤੁ ਸਚੌ ਤਖਤੁ ਜੋਗ ਭੋਗ ਸੰਜੁਤੁ ਬਲਿ ॥

translation.text: He is seated upon the Throne of Truth, with the canopy above His Head; He is embellished with the powers of Yoga and the enjoyment of pleasures.

transliteration.text: sir ātapat sachau takhat jōg bhōg sanjut bal .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਸਚੁ ਸਲ੍ਯ ਭਣਿ ਤੂ ਅਟਲੁ ਰਾਜਿ ਅਭਗੁ ਦਲਿ ॥੧॥

translation.text: So speaks SALL the poet: O Guru Raam Daas, Your sovereign power is eternal and unbreakable; Your army is invincible. ||1||

transliteration.text: gur rāmadās sach saly bhan tū atal rāj abhag dal .1.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਤੂ ਸਤਿਗੁਰੁ ਚਹੁ ਜੁਗੀ ਆਪਿ ਆਪੇ ਪਰਮੇਸਰੁ ॥

translation.text: You are the True Guru, throughout the four ages; You Yourself are the Transcendent Lord.

transliteration.text: tū satigur chah jugī āp āpē paramēsar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਸੁਰਿ ਨਰ ਸਾਧਿਕ ਸਿਧ ਸਿਖ ਸੇਵੰਤ ਧੁਰਹ ਧੁਰੁ ॥

translation.text: The angelic beings, seekers, Siddhas and Sikhs have served You, since the very beginning of time.

transliteration.text: sur nar sādhik sidh sikh sēvant dhurah dhur .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਆਦਿ ਜੁਗਾਦਿ ਅਨਾਦਿ ਕਲਾ ਧਾਰੀ ਤ੍ਰਿਹੁ ਲੋਅਹ ॥

translation.text: You are the Primal Lord God, from the very beginning, and throughout the ages; Your Power supports the three worlds.

transliteration.text: ād jugād anād kalā dhārī trih lōah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਅਗਮ ਨਿਗਮ ਉਧਰਣ ਜਰਾ ਜੰਮਿਹਿ ਆਰੋਅਹ ॥

translation.text: You are Inaccessible; You are the Saving Grace of the Vedas. You have conquered old age and death.

transliteration.text: agam nigam udharan jarā janmih ārōah .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:
Poet Salh [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਗੁਰ ਅਮਰਦਾਸਿ ਥਿਰੁ ਥਪਿਅਉ ਪਰਗਾਮੀ ਤਾਰਣ ਤਰਣ ॥

translation.text: Guru Amar Daas has permanently established You; You are the Emancipator, to carry all across to the other side.

transliteration.text: gur amaradās thir thapiau paragāmī tāran taran .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Salh
author.description:

Poet Salh wrote three hymns, one in praise of Guru Amar Das, the third Guru, and two in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru. Poet Salh and Poet Bhalh were brothers, both sons of Sokha.

text: ਅਘ ਅੰਤਕ ਬਦੈ ਨ ਸਲ੍ਯ ਕਵਿ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਤੇਰੀ ਸਰਣ ॥੨॥੬੦॥

translation.text: So speaks SALL the poet: O Guru Raam Daas, You are the Destroyer of sins; I seek Your Sanctuary. ||2||60||

transliteration.text: agh antak badai n saly kav gur rāmadās tērī saran .2.60.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
